content: Military police officer indicted on child porn charges EL PASO -- A military police officer from Fort Bliss has been indicted on child pornography charges and faces a preliminary hearing Tuesday in U.S. District Court. The suspect is Staff Sgt. Grady Michael Riley, 33, who was arrested Monday by Immigration Customs Enforcement agents at Fort Bliss, said Leticia Zamarripa, an ICE spokeswoman. Zamarripa said an investigation of Riley began about a year ago. >http://www.elpasotimes.com/military/ci_11985018
reply: Military police officer indicted on child porn charges EL PASO -- A military police officer from Fort Bliss has been indicted on child pornography charges and faces a preliminary hearing Tuesday in U.S. District Court. The suspect is Staff Sgt. Grady Michael Riley, 33, who was arrested Monday by Immigration Customs Enforcement agents at Fort Bliss, said Leticia Zamarripa, an ICE spokeswoman. Zamarripa said an investigation of Riley began about a year ago. >http://www.elpasotimes.com/military/ci_11985018

God bless all who wear the the uniform of "law enforcement" and THANK YOU, for your willingness to stand up for me and mine and never have met us... Yours is a true calling... content: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: quote: Originally posted by SUNLINER81: quote: Originally posted by IHAWKER: Military police officer indicted on child porn charges EL PASO -- A military police officer from Fort Bliss has been indicted on child pornography charges and faces a preliminary hearing Tuesday in U.S. District Court. Zamarripa said an investigation of Riley began about a year ago. >http://www.elpasotimes.com/military/ci_11985018 When an officer of the law, whether civilian or military, is suspect, it unfortunately, reflects badly on all who stand in the cold of the night or the blaze of the noonday heat, to protect us all... God bless all who wear the the uniform of "law enforcement" and THANK YOU, for your willingness to stand up for me and mine and never have met us... Yours is a true calling... Most Respectfully, SUNLINER81 wonder if you feel that way when a cop (non mil) zaps you with a taser for speeding.. And what did you do, to get him/her to zap you with a tazer for speeding?... I come from a law enforcement family and one that has served this nation in the military in war and peace... That having been said, I have yet to run into any sworn officer of the law, that has treated me with nothing but respect when I have "earned" a traffic ticket... I have never had any law enforcement officer mistreat me in any way what so ever!... The rule of thumb is, treat an officer of the law with the same respect as you would have him/her treat you... Now, as to what I said earlier, anyone who will go out and take a bullet for another person and that persons family and never even have met them, is pretty d@mned fine in my book!... If you ever need a cop at 0200hrs, if you think that they are that bad as to "zap you with a tazer during a traffic stop", then call the local wino and get him/her to come and save your azz!... Respectfully, SUNLINER81 This message has been edited. Last edited by: SUNLINER81, Tue 24 March 2009 11:27 PM

content: I was testifying on a difficult case. It was a DWI-fatal, left scene, pedestrian accident. The pedestrian was projected 33 feet into some bushes where he laid out overnight and bled to death. The Medical Examiner said he would've survived if he had received immediate attention. I noticed a young man listening to every word I said. He even seemed to nod and smile at me one point. I mentioned this to the ADA during a break. She replied, "The tall guy with red hair?". When I said yes, she explained that he had a recent DWI conviction. I asked if this would hurt us. She said no; in that, the juror said earlier, "I paid for my DWI, this SOB will pay for his". Not only my juror had a predisposition favorable to law enforcement, but there's some cop out there who treated the citizen right during the first DWI arrest. The motorist wasn't embarrassed, ridiculed, or mistreated. He also took the hit like a man. The defendant was convicted upon trial and served 4 years for the death. The conviction was upheld by the Court of Appeals. Since then our State Legislature has strengthened DWI laws making these deaths more serious. I don't think a speeding ticket would usually make a good citizen that angry to change his/ her entire philosophy. Stay safe. Please make sure you use your seatbelt
reply: I was testifying on a difficult case. It was a DWI-fatal, left scene, pedestrian accident. The pedestrian was projected 33 feet into some bushes where he laid out overnight and bled to death. The Medical Examiner said he would've survived if he had received immediate attention. I noticed a young man listening to every word I said. He even seemed to nod and smile at me one point. I mentioned this to the ADA during a break. She replied, "The tall guy with red hair?". When I said yes, she explained that he had a recent DWI conviction. I asked if this would hurt us. She said no; in that, the juror said earlier, "I paid for my DWI, this SOB will pay for his". Not only my juror had a predisposition favorable to law enforcement, but there's some cop out there who treated the citizen right during the first DWI arrest. The motorist wasn't embarrassed, ridiculed, or mistreated. He also took the hit like a man. The defendant was convicted upon trial and served 4 years for the death. The conviction was upheld by the Court of Appeals. Since then our State Legislature has strengthened DWI laws making these deaths more serious. I don't think a speeding ticket would usually make a good citizen that angry to change his/ her entire philosophy. Stay safe. Please make sure you use your seatbelt

content: quote: Originally posted by crackerjacks61: wonder if you feel that way when a cop (non mil) zaps you with a taser for speeding.. How many times have you been tased for speeding? You make it sound like it happens all the time. It doesn't! I'm a LEO in a city of over 500,000 and nobody here has ever been tased for speeding. Stop being ridiculous. LEO's in our Jurisdiction issue a few hundred speeding tickets every day...and not one taser incident.

content: I find it interesting how threads get derailed onto topics that the derailer has a pet peav for. Then even more interesting that said derailer has no notable real experience in the matter to which it has been derailed. That would be either generally or specifically. Anyway, truely a sad day for Law Enforcement. It's always an embarrassment when an LEO gives in to temptations. LEO's are held to a higher standard as they/we should be. Make a mistake (albiet criminal in this case) and you make national news. Anyone else does the same thing and they wind up in section C page 6 if anyone notices at all.

content: BTW, the last time I got a speeding ticket(80 in a 55), I saw the trooper, knew I was hit. I started to pull over almost right when I went past him. We had made eye contact & he had "that look". He comes up to the car & I sheepishly smiled & said, "how bad?" he said "80". I apologized, he wrote it up as 70(BIG difference in the fine). I went on my way. I guess he forgot to tase me.
reply: BTW, the last time I got a speeding ticket(80 in a 55), I saw the trooper, knew I was hit. I started to pull over almost right when I went past him. content: quote: Originally posted by FlankerFlyer: someone fuqqed up their life forever. We had a SFC in Germay back in '83 who got caught messing with his 6 y/o daughters. I think he is still a Pvt E-0 in Manheim. The Sgt escorting him there pulled out his .45 and begged the (then) prisoner to be to try something. He had a blank expression on his face as he was escorted into the van in front of the company. "When you look into an abyss, the abyss also looks into you." ~~ Friedrich Nietzsche
